title: Leader in Renewable Energy Usage
description: In 2023, Iceland utilized 89.33% of its total energy from alternative and nuclear sources, showcasing its commitment to sustainable energy solutions.

title: Top Electric Power Consumer Per Capita
description: With an electric power consumption of 50,082.75 kWh per capita in 2023, Iceland ranks among the highest in the world, reflecting its robust energy infrastructure.

title: Abundant Freshwater Resources
description: In 2021, Iceland boasted 456,351.34 cubic meters of renewable internal freshwater resources per capita, highlighting its rich natural water reserves.

title: Universal Financial Inclusion
description: By 2021, 100% of Iceland's population aged 15+ had access to financial institutions or mobile-money services, indicating comprehensive financial inclusion.

title: High Female Primary School Enrollment
description: In 2016, 99.37% of females were enrolled in primary education, underscoring Iceland's commitment to gender equality in education.

title: Complete Male Persistence to Grade 5
description: By 2021, 100% of male students persisted to grade 5, reflecting a strong educational system that supports student retention.

title: Minimal Agricultural Irrigation
description: In 2021, only 0.0027% of Iceland's agricultural land was irrigated, indicating a reliance on natural precipitation for farming.

title: Low Carbon Emissions from Agriculture
description: Iceland's agricultural sector emitted just 0.0008 Mt CO2e in 2023, showcasing its environmentally friendly farming practices.

title: Negligible Natural Resource Depletion
description: In 2021, natural resources depletion accounted for only 0.0001% of Iceland's GNI, reflecting sustainable resource management.

title: Minimal Freshwater Use in Agriculture
description: Agriculture accounted for just 0.11% of Iceland's total freshwater withdrawals in 2021, highlighting efficient water use.

title: Low Pupil-Teacher Ratio in Preprimary Education
description: In 2015, Iceland had a pupil-teacher ratio of 4.77 in preprimary education, ensuring personalized attention for young learners.

title: Minimal Over-age Students in Primary Education
description: In 2017, only 0.034% of primary students in Iceland were over-age, indicating timely progression through the education system.

title: Low Child Mortality Rate
description: In 2023, the probability of dying among children aged 5-9 in Iceland was just 0.2 per 1,000, reflecting excellent child healthcare.

title: Minimal Youth Not in Education or Employment
description: In 2023, only 2.62% of Icelandic female youth were not in education, employment, or training, indicating strong youth engagement.

title: Low Net ODA Contribution
description: In 2022, Iceland provided $94.38 million in net ODA, reflecting a modest contribution to international aid.

title: Minimal Chemicals in Manufacturing
description: In 2020, chemicals accounted for a negative percentage of value added in Iceland's manufacturing sector, indicating limited industrial chemical use.

title: Low Forest Depletion
description: In 2021, Iceland's net forest depletion was valued at just $27,386, showcasing effective forest conservation efforts.

title: Negligible Natural Resources Rents
description: In 2021, total natural resources rents contributed only 0.0001% to Iceland's GDP, indicating limited reliance on natural resource extraction.

title: Low Incidence of Low-Birthweight Babies
description: In 2020, only 3.99% of births in Iceland were low-birthweight, reflecting good maternal and infant health care.
